**Zhang Ziyang’s Song for Daoist Liu of White Dragon Cave**

Hare runs, crow flies—both suns hasten,
First blooms the flower, then autumn frost descends.
Vainly boast of a thousand years’ wealth and longevity,
Yet all is but a lightning flash amid the clouds.

A lightning flash—how fleeting!
A hundred years, thirty-six thousand days,
Through scorching heat and freezing cold,
Unseen, youth’s glow fades in darkness.
Though children and grandchildren fill one’s sight,
All become bonds of love, entangling ever tighter.
When essence is exhausted and the body withers,
Who can devise a way to briefly stay the course?

No way to stay—no plan remains,
Inevitably, the body follows the flowing waters.
Behold the sages and worthies of old—
How many knew the art of abiding in the world?

Yet abiding in the world has its method,
Only because men of this age misjudge.
They scramble into the mountains seeking herbs and trees,
Refining lead, restraining mercury, concocting cinnabar yang.

Concocting cinnabar yang—how different the task!
One must seek crimson blood in the Kan palace,
Then take it to the Li position to refine yin essence.
Kan embodies Kun’s body, Li embodies Qian’s body.
Qian’s yang unites with Kun to form Kan—
This is called "flowing wu."
Kun’s yin unites with Qian to give birth to Li—
This is called "returning ji."
All things gestate in the *zi* hour;
Qian’s *ren* and Kun’s *gui* meet in the north,
Hence called the Kan palace—
The Kan palace is the Kun palace.
The southwest is the native land,
Not the positions of *wei* and *shen*.
Primal qi arises from this.
Crimson blood is the single yang essence within the body,
Also called yang lead—
Truly, the primordial unity of qi.

The Classic says: "How sublime!
True lead, prior to heaven and earth,
This is true lead."
The Li position is the Qian palace.
Know the time to gather this yang lead,
Use it to refine the yin essence of the Li position—
Yin essence is yin mercury,
The liquid of wood.
When these two substances unite,
They form the inner elixir—
Not the cinnabar or mercury of the world,
Nor the metals, minerals, herbs, or tangible things.

The blending must follow its season,
The medicine’s flavor mild,
Gold and water in equal measure.
The Yellow Dame serves as matchmaker,
Seeking union in marriage.
The key lies in knowing the season—
The season requires the matchmaker.

*The Kinship of the Three* says:
"From the dark of the moon to dawn,
Zhen arrives to receive the tally."
This is the time when the first yang stirs.
At this moment,
The female dragon hums,
The male tiger roars.
With the matchmaker, they unite of themselves—
The matchmaker is the Yellow Dame.

An ancient song says:
"Three and four dwell together in one chamber,
One and two, husband and wife, become a pair.
Only with a good matchmaker may they wed,
Thus their union deepens in affection."

Ziyang says:
"Originally, wu and ji served as matchmakers,
Thus husband and wife remain in joyful union."
He also says:
"One must rely on the matchmaker’s guidance."

Master Shi says:
"Who understands the workings?
The gist lies with the Yellow Dame."
Thus, the Yellow Dame is true earth,
True earth is the Yellow Dame.
When the male and female unite,
Hard and soft intertwine inseparably—
None but the Yellow Dame can accomplish this.
She is the pivot of the returning elixir,
The embankment of metal and water,
The center where the Way flows freely,
Rightly positioned within the body,
Beauty dwelling therein.
The Yellow Dame, true earth—
Her great outline is now revealed!

The Golden Duke and the Radiant Maiden wed.
The Golden Duke and the Radiant Maiden—
Their meanings are explained below.
Their union is the merging of lead and mercury.
The Golden Duke favors riding the White Tiger.
The Golden Duke is lead,
Embracing the essence of Heavenly One,
Born of the moon and lodged in the west’s *geng* and *xin* metal,
Emerging from the Kan position.
Thus it is said: "The tiger is born in water"—
Silver within lead,
White within black,
Gold within water.

*The Kinship of the Three* says:
"Metal is the mother of water,
The mother conceals the child’s embryo."
Water is metal’s child,
The child hides in the mother’s womb.
It also says:
"Clad in coarse cloth, yet holding jade,
Outwardly a madman."

chunks.original_text: 乃真铅也，实先天之一炁耳。 姹女常驾赤龙身。 姹女汞也，汞负正阳之气，本从日生而寄质於东方甲乙木，而出於离官，故曰龙从火裹出，即砂中汞，雄裹雌，太阳流珠也。 《参同契》曰：汞曰为流珠，青龙与之俱。 又经曰：赤髓流为汞，媳女弄明当。 乃真汞也，木液是矣！ 虎来静坐秋江裹，龙向碧潭奋身起， 秋江即是西江碧潭，即是东海真龙，见真虎则一起一伏，两相饮食，俱相贪便。 两兽相逢战一场，波浪奔腾如鼎沸。 古歌曰：青龙逐虎虎寻龙，赤禽交会声嗈嗈。 是龙争虎战，水激火发，鼎沸暴涌，颠倒受制，时有婴儿之声。 黄婆丁老助威灵， 石真人云：黄婆双乳美，丁老片心慈，龙虎相交战，束君总不知。 黄婆见前释，丁老乃文火也。 阴真君曰：我为世上道无穷，不知只伏婴儿心。 真漏泄天机也。 撼动乾坤走神鬼， 古歌曰：圣人夺得造化意，手搏日月安炉裹，微微腾倒天地精，捞簇阴阳走神鬼。 神鬼即天魂地魄。 须臾战罢云气收， 云收雨散，万籁净返，掌中间夹变福。 种个玄珠在泥底。 《复命篇》曰：夜来混沌撷落地，万象森罗总不知。 乃一点落黄庭也。 黄庭即中官黄房也，玄关也，喻如泥底也。 紫阳曰：一时辰内管丹成，为一日之丹就也。 日添一黍米大，渐渐成玄珠也。 黄帝赤水求玄珠，非罔象无由得之，是此珠也，罔象无思无虑也。 从此根芽渐长成，时时灌溉抱真精， 三谷子曰：立基一百日，温养以周星，但当保精音神，水自滋，火自养，待其气足。 十月脱胎吞入腹，忽觉凡躯已有灵。 紫阳又曰：一粒灵丹吞入腹。 又日脱胎，又曰通神圣。 《参同契》曰：金砂入五内，雾散若风雨。 既是内丹，如何又曰入腹入口入五内？ 后人疑此，便为外丹。 殊不知无质生质，乃谓还丹。 真一子所谓首探天地真一混沌之气，而为根基； 继取乾坤精粹，潜运之踪而为法象； 循坎离否泰之数，而为刑德，盗阴阳变化之机，而成冬夏。 阴生午后，阳发子初，故以乾坤为鼎器，以坎离为药物，余六十卦为火候，烹炼温养，潜夺化工。 如果生枝上，子在胞中，十月火侯气足，则倏尔而蜕神入真胎，与天相毕矣！ 故云入口入腹入五内。 《参同契》曰：类如鸡子，白黑相符，纵广一寸，以为始初。 四肢五脏，筋骨乃俱，弥历十月，脱出其胞。 可谓无质生质，身外有身，恋故躯则困在昏衢，出泥九则纵横天地，名题仙籍，位号真人，乃大丈夫功成名遂之时也。 此个事，世间稀，不是等闲人得知，夙世若无仙骨分，容易如何得遇之。 得遇之，宜速炼，都绿光景急如箭，爱取鱼儿须结肾，莫使临渊空叹羡。 闻君知药已多年，何不收心炼汞铅，莫教烛被风吹灭，六道轮回难怨天。 此语警刘仙，且教其收心炼汞铅，以此见内丹须自己内炼，非假外药分晓。 近来世人多诡诈，竞着布衣称道者，问他金木是何般，噤口无言低害哑。 金木见《指要》中金木交并释云：修丹不知此，不可与语还丹矣！ 却云服气与休粮，别有门庭道理长，君不见《破迷歌》裹说，太一含真法最强。 旁门小法千条万绪，於金液还返内丹之道，了无干涉。 所谓如何却是道，太一含真气，五星连珠，日月合璧也。 内丹从此而结，法身从此而出，别无第二门也。

True lead is indeed the primordial qi.
The Radiant Maiden ever rides the Crimson Dragon’s form.

The Radiant Maiden is mercury,
Bearing the essence of pure yang,
Born of the sun and lodged in the east’s *jia* and *yi* wood,
Emerging from the Li palace.
Thus it is said: "The dragon issues from fire"—
Mercury within cinnabar,
Yang within yin,
The sun’s flowing pearl.

*The Kinship of the Three* says:
"Mercury is called the flowing pearl,
The Green Dragon accompanies it."
Another scripture states:
"Crimson marrow flows as mercury,
The maiden plays with brightness at dawn."
This is true mercury—
The liquid of wood!

The tiger comes to sit quietly in the autumn river,
The dragon stirs its body in the azure pool.
The autumn river is the western river’s azure pool,
The true dragon of the eastern sea—
At the sight of the true tiger, one rises as the other sinks,
Both covetous, each devouring the other.

The two beasts meet in battle,
Waves surging like a seething cauldron.
An ancient song says:
"The Green Dragon pursues the tiger, the tiger seeks the dragon,
The red birds unite with clamorous cries."
As dragon contends with tiger,
Water clashes with fire,
The cauldron seethes and roils,
Inversion and restraint arise,
And the infant’s cry is heard.

The Yellow Dame and Elder Ding lend their mighty power.
The True Stone Man says:
"The Yellow Dame’s twin breasts are fair,
Elder Ding’s single heart is kind.
As dragon and tiger wage war,
The lord remains unaware."
The Yellow Dame was explained earlier;
Elder Ding is the gentle fire.

Master Yin Zhen says:
"I am the Dao of boundless worlds,
Yet know only to subdue the infant’s heart."
This truly reveals heaven’s secret.

The quaking shakes heaven and earth, startling gods and spirits.
An ancient song says:
"The sage seizes the workings of creation,
Grasping sun and moon to place within the furnace.
Gently inverting the essence of heaven and earth,
Gathering yin and yang to rouse gods and spirits."
Gods and spirits are the celestial soul and earthly spirit.

In an instant, the battle ceases and the mists disperse,
Clouds withdraw, rain scatters, all returns to silence—
Within the palm, fortune is transformed.
A mysterious pearl is planted in the mud’s depths.

*The Return of Life* says:
"At night, chaos falls to earth,
The myriad forms vanish without trace."
This is the single point descending into the Yellow Court—
The Yellow Court is the central palace, the Yellow Chamber,
The mysterious pass, likened to the mud’s depths.

Master Ziyang says:
"Within one double-hour, the elixir is complete"—
The elixir is achieved in a single day.
Day by day, it grows by a grain of millet,
Gradually forming the mysterious pearl.

The Yellow Emperor sought the mysterious pearl in the Crimson Waters,
Yet without Vast Image, it could not be obtained—
This is that very pearl,
Vast Image being thoughtless and carefree.

From this, the root and sprout gradually mature,
Constantly nourished by the embrace of true essence.
The Three Valleys Master says:
"Establish the foundation for a hundred days,
Then nurture it through the full cycle of the stars.
Simply guard the essence, spirit, and sound,
Water will naturally moisten, fire will naturally nurture,
Waiting until the qi is full."

After ten months, the embryo is shed, and the elixir is swallowed into the belly,
Suddenly, the mortal frame is felt to possess spirit.
Master Ziyang also says:
"A grain of the sacred elixir is swallowed into the belly."
Again, it is called "shedding the embryo,"
And "communing with the divine and sagely."

*The Kinship of the Three* says:
"Golden sand enters the five viscera,
Mist scatters like wind and rain."
If this is the inner elixir,
How can it be said to enter the belly, the mouth, the five viscera?
Later generations, doubting this, took it for an external elixir.
Yet they did not know that from formlessness comes form—
This is called the Returned Elixir.

The True Unity Master said:
"First, plumb the primordial chaotic qi of heaven and earth as the foundation;
Then, gather the essence of qian and kun, subtly moving their traces to form the image;
Follow the numbers of kan and li, pi and tai to establish punishment and virtue;
Steal the mechanism of yin and yang’s transformations to complete winter and summer.
Yin arises after noon, yang stirs at midnight’s beginning.
Thus, qian and kun serve as the crucible and vessel,
Kan and li as the medicinal substances,
The remaining sixty hexagrams as the fire times.
Refining, nurturing, and subtly seizing the work of transformation—
Like fruit growing on a branch,
The child within the womb,
After ten months, the fire times and qi are full,
Then suddenly, the spirit sheds and enters the true embryo,
Uniting with heaven!"

Thus it is said to enter the mouth, the belly, the five viscera.
*The Kinship of the Three* says:
"Like a chicken’s egg,
White and black align,
A span of one inch in length and breadth,
As the beginning.
The four limbs, five viscera, sinews, and bones are all complete,
After ten months, it emerges from the womb."
This is truly from formlessness comes form,
A body beyond the body.
Clinging to the old frame traps one in darkness,
Emerging from the ninth mud is to roam heaven and earth,
Inscribed in the immortal register,
Titled as a True Person—
The moment when the great man’s work is accomplished and his name is achieved.

This matter is rare in the world,
Not known to ordinary people.
If one lacks the immortal’s bone from past lives,
How could it be easily encountered?
Having encountered it, refine it swiftly—
The passing scenery flies like an arrow.
To catch the fish, one must cast the net;
Do not stand by the pool and sigh in vain.

"I have heard you have known the medicine for many years,
Why not gather your heart and refine mercury and lead?
Do not let the candle be blown out by the wind,
For the six paths of rebirth leave no room to blame heaven."

These words admonish Immortal Liu,
Urging him to gather his heart and refine mercury and lead.
From this, it is clear that the inner elixir must be refined within oneself,
Not relying on external medicines for distinction.

Lately, worldly people are full of deceit,
Competing to don Daoist robes and claim the Way.
Ask them what metal and wood are—
They fall silent, mute and ashamed.

Metal and wood are explained in *Essential Pointers* under "Metal and Wood Intermingling":
"Without knowing this, one cannot speak of the Returned Elixir."
Yet they say it is about breath control and fasting,
Claiming another school with profound principles.
Have you not seen *The Song of Breaking Delusion*?
"The method of Embracing True Unity is strongest."

Side paths and minor arts number in the thousands,
Yet they have no relation to the Dao of the Golden Liquid’s return.
What is the Dao?
Embracing the true qi of Unity,
The five stars aligned in a string,
The sun and moon conjoined—
The inner elixir is formed from this,
The Dharma-body emerges from this,
There is no second gate.

chunks.original_text: 莫怪言辞甚乖劣，只为世人无鉴别，惟君心与我心同，方敢倾怀为君说。 规中图十二字诀序 三千六百法，养命数十家，率皆旁门，无非曲径。 且如服气鼓虚腹，肘后飞金晶，吸擂运河车，闭息为火候，纳清吐浊，接境诉流，引龟转输鲈，鉴形希超脱，存顶囱，守眉心，尽是头上安头，无事起事，颠倒失序，乖於至真。 遂使百脉沸腾，三田溃乱，本期永寿，反尔伤生。 良由逆天地之和，不合自然之旨。 故简易阅历《参同》仅三十载，颇得其奥，伸诸丹经，以其绪余，作《规中图十二字诀》，用传学道君子，以正心诚意，为主为中心柱子，处中以制外。 以八字为辅，调御四时，由外以应中。 上合天心，中稽人事，默符造化，顺轨阴阳，外法五行，内理五藏，以为日用循环无端也。 不施为也，不存想也，晏然大定，以总元机，但要绝嗜欲，定心气，省思虑，节饮食，调鼻息，警昏睡，怪视听，养天和。 於四威仪中，胳合自然，别无繁难也。 已立鄞鄂者，以是契符火养圣胎，未立鄞鄂者，以是益元气，养精神，为立鄞鄂之渐。 至於虚耗损失，病疾交攻，则以是驱疾固元，为补益延年，养命之术，可谓简易之门矣！ 规中图 规中者，如居一规之中，不在中间，不在内外也，不泥象也，不着物也，在身中之中，意中之中，如大圆镜中之一我，但正心诚意，为中心柱子，当万虑俱泯之时，真人出现，如鱼居深渊，游泳自在，而不离方寸，即真人潜深渊，浮游守规中矣！ 喜怒哀乐未发，当此之时，可以居规中，浮泳而潜御四时，以正造化。 四威仪中，不可失节焉！ 物来则应过，复居於中，切不可动着中心柱子。 於中常令空虚，一尘不立，久之不纵不拘，自得受用。 其要妙也，六阴归坤，万物还元，复卦始萌，长子继父体，一阳潜动处，万物未生时，皆从这裹起，便是作用处。 当斯时也，踟趺大坐，凝神内照，调息绵绵，默而守之，则一炁从虚无中来，杳杳冥冥，无色无形，兆於玄冥，坤癸之地，生于肾中，以育元精，补续元炁，续续不耗，日益日强。 始之去病，次以返婴，积为内丹之基本矣！ 土展真人云：所谓是元炁，补元炁，岂是凡砂。 此补益之上法也。 朝屯者，体君子经纶之始，是万物萌芽之初，仁之端也。 子时其始生之炁在肾，是不召而自来，宜宝而养之。 调息无令耳闻，但听其悠悠绵绵，合乎自然，与天地秦钥相应，久之则肾炁合心炁，二炁交感，以降甘露，而产玄珠焉！ 暮蒙者，蒙以养正，圣功也，不失赤子之心也。 午时其始生之炁在心，无思无虑，寂然不动，冥心内照，以合之。 是宜静坐以敛之，久之则心炁自合肾炁，而成既济之功焉！ 人居三才之一，一身与天地等，故与天地之炁相应，真一之精相符。 人之元炁八百一十丈，橐钥相似，所以元炁大运随天，小运随日，但人不能体法天地，以致断丧伤败，精神迷乱，自与之违，岂天地违之也哉！ 若能顺其理，挃其机，则可以符化工而为修丹，内炼长生久视之道也。 除人之外，总皆禀浊混淆，而在元炁中，均为化物耳。 又安能御元炁者哉？ 《参同契》云：春夏据内体，从子到辰巳，秋冬当外用，自午讫戌亥。 又云：赏罚应春秋，昏明顺寒暑，爻辞有仁义，随时发喜怒，如是应四时，五行得其理。

**Preface to the Twelve-Character Secret of the Regulated Center Diagram**

Three thousand six hundred methods,
Tens of schools for nurturing life—
All are side paths, nothing but crooked trails.
Take, for instance, breath-holding to inflate the belly,
The "Flying Golden Essence" behind the elbow,
Absorbing and grinding to move the River Chariot,
Breath retention as the fire-timing,
Inhaling clarity and exhaling turbidity,
Connecting with realms to channel flows,
Guiding the turtle and rotating the perch,
Mirroring form to seek transcendence,
Preserving the top vent,
Guarding the space between the brows—
All are piling heads upon heads,
Creating affairs where none exist,
Disordering the sequence,
Deviating from the utmost truth.
Thus they cause the hundred vessels to seethe,
The Three Fields to erupt in chaos,
Hoping for eternal life,
Yet only harming their own.
This stems from opposing the harmony of Heaven and Earth,
Failing to align with the principle of spontaneity.

After thirty years of simplifying and reviewing the *Can Tong Qi*,
I have grasped its mysteries.
Comparing it with other alchemical classics,
I distilled its essential threads
To compose the *Twelve-Character Secret of the Regulated Center Diagram*,
Transmitting it to those who study the Dao,
To rectify the heart and sincerify the will,
Making them the central pillar,
The axis within that governs the without.
Eight characters serve as auxiliaries,
Regulating the four seasons,
Responding from without to within.
Above, it harmonizes with the heart of Heaven;
In the middle, it examines human affairs;
Silently conforming to creation,
Following the track of yin and yang,
Externally modeling the Five Phases,
Internally ordering the Five Viscera—
Thus it becomes the endless cycle of daily use.
No action is taken,
No visualization is held.
In serene great stability,
The primal mechanism is grasped.
Only require:
Cutting off desires,
Stilling the heart and qi,
Reducing thoughts,
Moderating diet,
Regulating breath,
Guarding against drowsiness,
Restraining sight and sound,
Nurturing Heaven’s harmony.
Within the four dignified postures,
Align with spontaneity—
No complexity or difficulty exists.

For those who have established the *yinqie* (silver enclosure),
This serves to harmonize with the fire and nurture the sacred embryo.
For those who have not yet established the *yinqie*,
This strengthens the primal qi,
Nourishes the spirit,
And serves as the gradual foundation for establishing the *yinqie*.
When depletion, loss, or illness assails,
This drives away sickness and secures the primal,
Serving as a method for supplementation, longevity,
And the art of nurturing life—
Truly the simplest of gates!

**The Regulated Center Diagram**

The "Regulated Center" is like dwelling within a compass’s circle—
Neither inside nor outside,
Neither clinging to images
Nor attaching to things.
It is the center within the body,
The center within the mind,
Like the "I" within a great round mirror.
Simply rectify the heart and sincerify the will,
Making them the central pillar.
When all thoughts are extinguished,
The true person appears—
Like a fish dwelling in the deep abyss,
Swimming freely yet never leaving the square inch.
Thus the true person lurks in the deep abyss,
Floating and guarding the Regulated Center.

When joy, anger, sorrow, and delight have not yet arisen,
At this time, one can reside in the Regulated Center,
Floating and swimming to govern the four seasons,
Rectifying creation.
Within the four dignified postures,
One must not lose proper measure!
When things come, respond and let them pass,
Then return to the center—
But never disturb the central pillar.
Within the center, maintain emptiness,
Not a speck of dust arises.
Over time, neither indulgence nor restraint,
One naturally attains its benefits.
Its subtlety lies in:
The six yin returning to Kun,
The myriad things returning to the origin,
The *Fu* hexagram’s first sprouting,
The eldest son inheriting the father’s body,
The solitary yang stirring in concealment—
The time before the myriad things arise.
All begins here—
This is the point of application.

At this moment,
Sit cross-legged in great stillness,
Concentrate the spirit and inwardly illuminate,
Regulate the breath to be continuous and soft,
Silently guard it.
Then the qi arises from the formless,
Vast and obscure,
Without color or shape,
Emerging in the profound darkness,
The region of Kun and Gui,
Born within the kidneys,
To nurture the primal essence,
Supplement and continue the primal qi,
Unceasing and unexhausted,
Growing stronger day by day.
First, it dispels illness;
Next, it returns to infancy.
Accumulated, it becomes the foundation of the inner elixir!

Master Tuzhen said:
"This is the primal qi,
Supplementing the primal qi—
How could it be mere common cinnabar?"
This is the supreme method of supplementation.

**Morning Layering (Zhaotun):**
The body of the noble one begins its governance,
The first sprouting of the myriad things,
The inception of benevolence.
At the *zi* hour, the qi of initial generation resides in the kidneys—
It comes unbidden, so treasure and nurture it.
Regulate the breath so the ears do not hear,
Simply listen to its gentle, continuous flow,
Aligning with spontaneity,
Resonating with the key of Heaven and Earth.
Over time, kidney qi merges with heart qi,
The two qi interact,
Descending as sweet dew,
And producing the mysterious pearl!

**Evening Enveloping (Mumeng):**
Enveloping to nurture correctness—
The sagely work,
Not losing the heart of the infant.
At the *wu* hour, the qi of initial generation resides in the heart.
Without thought or worry,
Still and unmoving,
Inwardly illuminate in profound silence to unite with it.
Sit in stillness to gather it.
Over time, heart qi naturally merges with kidney qi,
Achieving the work of *Jiji* (Completion).

Humans reside within the Three Powers,
Their body equaling Heaven and Earth,
Thus their qi corresponds with Heaven and Earth,
Their true unity’s essence conforms.
A person’s primal qi spans eight hundred ten *zhang*,
Resembling the bellows—
The great movement of primal qi follows Heaven,
The lesser movement follows the sun.
Yet people cannot embody and model Heaven and Earth,
Leading to severance, damage, and ruin,
Spirit and essence confused and disordered,
Deviating from them on their own—
How could Heaven and Earth deviate from them?

If one can follow its principles,
Grasp its mechanism,
Then one can align with the work of creation
And engage in the Dao of inner refinement,
The path of long life and enduring vision.
Apart from humans, all else is endowed with turbid confusion,
Existing within the primal qi,
Merely transformed things—
How could they govern the primal qi?

The *Can Tong Qi* states:
"In spring and summer, rely on the inner body,
From *zi* to *chen-si*;
In autumn and winter, act externally,
From *wu* to *xu-hai*."
It also says:
"Rewards and punishments correspond to spring and autumn,
Dawn and dusk follow cold and heat.
The hexagram lines contain benevolence and righteousness,
Timely expressing joy and anger.
Thus responding to the four seasons,
The Five Phases attain their principles."

Thus, *zi*, *chou*, and *yin* correspond to spring; *mao*, *chen*, and *si* to summer; *wu*, *wei*, and *shen* to autumn; *you*, *xu*, and *hai* to winter.

*Zi*, *chou*, and *yin* align with spring, when Wood prevails. Wood governs benevolence, the time when the myriad things sprout forth. Hence, the two words *xi* (flourishing) and *he* (harmony) nurture it—*xi* as in the radiant joy of spring’s ascent to the terrace. *He* means beauty: the golden mean penetrating principle, dwelling in its rightful place within the body, flowing through the four limbs, manifesting in one’s undertakings—this is the perfection of beauty. Like an infant not yet able to laugh, crying without hoarseness, this is the perfection of harmony. Unaware of the union of male and female, yet the genitalia stir—this is the perfection of essence.

*Mao*, *chen*, and *si* align with summer, when Fire prevails. Fire governs ritual, the time when the myriad things flourish in order. Thus, the two words *zhong* (centeredness) and *he* (harmony) nurture it. Once harmony is achieved, there is neither excess nor deficiency—this is called *zhong* (the mean). Only then can the emotions and nature roam freely without turbulence.

*Wu*, *wei*, and *shen* align with autumn, when Metal prevails. Metal governs righteousness, the time when grasses and trees yellow and wither, and the myriad things are harvested. Hence, the two words *lian* (restraint) and *jing* (stillness) cultivate it, fulfilling the nature of the myriad things.

*You*, *xu*, and *hai* align with winter, when Water prevails. Water governs wisdom, the time when the myriad things return to their roots and the primal *qi* begins its solemn retreat. Thus, the two words *lian* (restraint) and *su* (solemnity) conceal it, aligning with the *qi* of Heaven and Earth.

The *Can Tong Qi* states:
"The true person abides in the deep abyss,
Floating and roaming, guarding the compass within."

The "true person" is none other than the one true self: when congealed, it is spirit; when in use, it is the heart; when still, it is nature. Neither moving nor still, empty yet spiritually penetrating—it is also called the true heart. It swims within the compass, within the square and circle of the rules, master of creation, moving without deviation, centered and responsive to the four seasons. chunks.original_text: 可谓要道不繁，工夫容易，离诸疑网，入众妙门。 某辄成七言四句，通宁真人诗一绝，共一十六首，按二十斤之数，直下注脚，用发玄机。 览者幸详味之，举一隅则头头俱是。 咸淳丙寅，修楔宜春晚学玉溪子序。 沁园赛 拈起话头便是道心事。 咦！ 好天良夜清明侯，赤子婴儿混沌时， 自得无弦琴裹趣，官商不许外人知。 七返还丹，金归性初，便是七返，得土成功，号曰九还。 情归性海称交并，炉冶金华号返还， 混养全资真土力，炼成灵质出尘寰。 在人，大道只在己身，内丹须是百炼。 太一分三人得一，大药只於身内觅， 可怜万万与千千，尽把将来为乐逸。 先须炼己待时。 炼己先要降心，采药自有时节。 拨转机关与俗乖，怡心寂澹似婴孩， 细看造物本无物，春到江南花自开。 正一阳初动，坤变成复，复其见天地之心乎！ 静坐蒲团绝所思，神庐出入渐迟迟， 氤氲暖气回天谷，知是一阳来复时。 中宵漏永，中宵便是午夜，漏裹始觉更长。 濒气腾腾万籁清，身中冬至恰三更， 可人风味孰能会，时听铜壶滴漏声。 温温铅鼎，鼎鼎非金鼎，炉炉非月炉，离从坎下起，兑在鼎中居。 玉兔汤煎濡沸驰，金炉火炽转光熹， 杳冥谁识无中有，内蕴金华是圣基。 光透帘帏，元神阳生，神光闪烁，冥心内照，一归冲漠。 始青一炁色非色，出彼龙楼归凤阙， 瑠璃箔下烛交辉，妇练江头雨初歇。 造化急驰，夫妇归室； 月到阳官，桃花浪裹，龙虎相逢。 红黑相投世莫猜，全凭戊己作良媒， 溶溶一掬乾坤髓，着意求他啜取来。 进火工夫犹斗危。 水中火发，雷裹花开，一意堤防，稳着方便。 鸿蒙官裹气氤氲，红杏枝头二月春， 但把金关牢锁闭，转机总是屋中珍。 曲江上看月华莹静，有个乌飞。 牛女缘情，道本龟蛇，类禀夫然，阳乌遇朔合婵娟，二气相资运转。 此是铅汞相投，莫认是小肠九曲。 宵真人诗云：曲江之上鹊桥横，牛女情缘，道本是也。 大药金丹自此生，不信但敲甲乙户，双童自解教君行。 甲乙户即如戊己门。 此内理至深远，笔舌难宣，但只是一身中事。 咦！ 要知山下路，但问去来人。 当时自饮刀圭，二土便是戊己，金刀即是铅汞。 龙盘虎踞镇中央，离坎交并日月光， 饮罢醒酬归洞府，华池郁郁藕花香。 又谁信无中养就儿。 身裹阴阳，壶中日月，一切仙圣，元来无别，不个中人，教我如何说？ 精养灵根气养神，化滋铅汞孕真身， 恍然透出泥丸顶，始信神仙不误人。 辨水源清浊，木金间隔，不因师指，此事难知。 铅沉银浮，清在上，浊在下，清为金华，浊为铅质。 以金华合木液，用铅之妙诀也。 二物会则情性混融，黍珠成则金木间隔，不因师指，此事难知。 清浊沉浮共一源，取清拾浊更玄玄， 混融间隔须分判，妙在师真一语传。 道要玄微，天机深远，下手速修犹太运。 学到知羞处，方知艺不精。 白云先生所谓毁之者如持巨蒂，以扫昆仑； 味之者类鸿鹄之饮沧海。 井蛙篱鹦之见，岂知海阔天高耶！ 勤而不遇。 终须遇，遇之不炼更愚痴。 当惜分阴，莫教虚度，直须猛省，急急修持，宝珠入手几时明，庵子坏了如何造？ 黍米珠中世界宽，仙真勃勃入其间，几多未遇徒瞻仰，空叹天高不可攀。 长春真人诗云：日月忽忽顶上飞，光阴忽忽眼前移，回头返顾即成老，下手速修犹太迟。

One might say the essential Dao is not complex, the work is easy—freeing oneself from the web of doubts to enter the gate of myriad wonders. I have composed sixteen seven-character quatrains, pairing each with a verse by Master Tongning, totaling twenty pounds in weight, and appended direct annotations to reveal the profound mechanism. May the reader savor them carefully, for grasping one corner reveals all others alike.

*Written in the late spring of the bingyin year of the Xianchun era, by the late learner Yuxizi of Yichun, during the Xiuxi festival.*

**Qinyuan Lyrics**

Lifting the topic at hand is the very matter of the Dao-heart.
Hark!
In the fine night of clear brightness,
In the chaos of the infant’s uncarved state,
One finds the delight of the stringless zither—
No notes of *gong* or *shang* may outsiders know.

The sevenfold return of the elixir,
Gold restored to its original nature,
This is the sevenfold return,
Achieving success through earth,
Called the ninefold restoration.
Passion returns to the sea of nature, termed the union,
The furnace refines golden radiance, named the return.
Nurtured wholly by the power of true earth,
Refined into a spirit-body, one emerges from the dusty world.

In man, the great Dao resides only within the self;
The inner elixir must be refined a hundredfold.
The Great One divides into three, yet man attains the one;
The great medicine is sought only within the body.
Pitiful are the ten thousand thousands,
Who take all this as mere pleasure and ease.

First, refine the self and await the moment.
Refining the self begins with subduing the heart;
The gathering of medicine has its own season.
Turning the mechanism sets one apart from the vulgar,
The heart serene and still as an infant.
Look closely: creation’s root is no-thing—
When spring arrives in Jiangnan, flowers bloom of themselves.

At the first stirring of the true yang,
*Kun* transforms into *Fu*—
Is this not the heart of heaven and earth revealed?
Sitting in stillness upon the rush mat, thoughts stilled,
The spirit’s abode breathes in and out, ever more slowly.
Warm, misty qi returns to the celestial valley—
Know this as the moment when yang begins its return.

In the deep of night, the water-clock endures;
Midnight is the hour when the night’s watch feels longest.
Steaming qi rises, all sounds hushed in clarity—
Within the body, winter solstice aligns with the third watch.
Who can fathom such delight?
Only the sound of the bronze clepsydra’s dripping remains.

Gently warmed, the lead crucible—
The crucible is no metal crucible,
The furnace no moon furnace.
*Li* arises from beneath *Kan*,
*Dui* resides within the crucible.
The jade hare’s decoction boils and surges,
The golden furnace’s fire blazes, its light growing bright.
Who perceives the existence within nothingness?
Within lies golden radiance—the foundation of the sage.

Light pierces the curtain,
The original spirit generates yang,
Divine light flickers—
The heart in profound stillness illumines inwardly,
All returns to the primordial void.
At first, the qi is azure, a color yet no-color,
Emerging from the dragon’s tower to return to the phoenix’s palace.
Beneath the lapis lazuli screen, candles glow in mutual brilliance,
By the river where women bleach silk, the rain has just ceased.

Creation’s pace hastens—
Husband and wife return to the chamber.
The moon reaches the yang palace,
Within the waves of peach blossoms,
Dragon and tiger meet.
Red and black unite, the world cannot guess—
All depends on *wu* and *ji* as the matchmaker.
A full ladle of the marrow of heaven and earth—
Seek it with intent and drink it in.

The work of advancing the fire is like treading a perilous path.
Fire arises within water,
Flowers bloom amid thunder—
Single-minded vigilance,
Steady and skillful.
Within the realm of primordial chaos, qi swirls and steams,
On the branch of red apricot, spring in its second month.
But keep the golden pass firmly sealed—
The turning mechanism is the treasure within the house.

By the winding river, the moon’s radiance gleams still—
A crow takes flight.
The oxherd and weaver girl’s bond,
The Dao’s root in tortoise and snake,
Innately so—
The yang crow meets the new moon, uniting in beauty,
The two qi mutually sustain and revolve.
This is the union of lead and mercury—
Do not mistake it for the nine bends of the small intestine.

Master Xiaozhen’s verse says:
Above the winding river, the magpie bridge spans,
The bond of oxherd and weaver girl—
This is the Dao itself.
The great medicine, the golden elixir, is born from this.
If you doubt, but knock at the *jia-yi* gate,
The twin youths will naturally guide you on your way.
The *jia-yi* gate is like the *wu-ji* portal.
Within this principle lies profound depth,
Beyond the reach of brush or tongue—
Yet it is merely a matter within the self.

Hark!
To know the path beneath the mountain,
Ask those who come and go.

At that time, one drinks the *daogui* of one’s own accord—
The two earths are *wu* and *ji*,
The golden blade is lead and mercury.
Dragon coiled, tiger crouched, guarding the center,
*Li* and *Kan* merge, the light of sun and moon.
After drinking, one awakens and returns to the grotto palace—
The flowery pond, lush with lotus fragrance.

Who would believe a child is nurtured within nothingness?
Within the body, yin and yang;
Within the pot, sun and moon—
All immortals and sages,
Originally no different.
If not one of those within,
How could I explain it to you?

Refine essence to nurture the spiritual root,
Refine qi to nurture the spirit—
Lead and mercury transform and nourish the true body.
Suddenly, one pierces through the mud-pill palace—
Only then does one trust that immortals do not deceive.

Discern the clarity and turbidity of the water’s source,
The separation of wood and metal—
Without a teacher’s guidance,
This matter is hard to know.
Lead sinks, silver floats—
The clear above, the turbid below.
The clear is golden radiance,
The turbid is lead’s essence.
To unite golden radiance with the liquid of wood—
This is the wondrous method of employing lead.
When the two meet, passion and nature merge;
When the millet pearl forms, wood and metal separate.
Without a teacher’s guidance,
This matter is hard to know.

The clear and turbid, sinking and floating, share a single source—
To take the clear and discard the turbid is even more profound.
The merging and separation must be distinguished—
The wonder lies in a single word from a true teacher.

The Dao is subtle and mysterious,
The celestial mechanism deep and distant—
Begin practice swiftly, for time is fleeting.
Only when one reaches the point of shame
Does one know one’s skill is not yet refined.

As Master Baiyun said:
Those who slander it are like grasping a giant melon stem to sweep Mount Kunlun;
Those who savor it are like swans and cranes drinking from the vast sea.
The views of the well-frog and fence-sparrow—
How could they know the vastness of sea and sky?

Diligence without encounter—
One must encounter it;
Encountering it without refinement is still folly.
Cherish each moment,
Do not let time pass in vain.
Awaken swiftly,
Practice urgently—
When will the precious pearl in hand shine clear?
If the hut is ruined, how can it be rebuilt?

Within the millet pearl, the world is vast—
The immortal true ones surge within.
How many gaze in vain,
Sighing at the heavens’ height, deeming it unattainable?

Master Changchun’s verse says:
Sun and moon swiftly fly overhead,
Time swiftly passes before one’s eyes.
Turning to look back, one is already old—
To begin practice swiftly is still too late.

chunks.original_text: 绍兴间，宜春城南魏安抚家多阴隐，一日有异人直入书齐中，呼安抚可来就语。 时魏昼寝，左右不敢以白，乃题一词於壁而去，名《苏幕遮》。 魏起，见而悔甚，使人寻觅，竟不可得。 词日：水中金冲牛斗，玉锁金关，护法灵童守。 赤水丹台。 龙虎走，万象森罗，勃勃投珠。 。 饮灵源明火侯，太一炉开，丹熟神光透。 浮名浮利终不久，下手速修，穷取无中有。 蓬莱路，仗三千行满，独步云归。 《虚皇经》云：几欲修道，建功为先。 是以诸天上帝，天帝高尊，诸天真人，诸天神仙，咸以功勤，超圣真位。 诸天记功，世间学人修真志恪，功满德就，凡蜕为仙，仙化为真，真人无碍，洞合自然。 消则为气，息则为人，神通自在，变化无形，飞行三界，出幽入冥。 修炼之士，始则惜精爱气，柄心凝神，自立基温养后。 乃入室三千，内功不可少亏，以至分胎纯熟，超脱朝元，尤资外行，以符天道。 是以功不厌多，行不厌广、是以功满三千，大罗为仙，行满三千，大罗为客。 锺离祖师云：有功无行如无足，有行无功足不前，功行两全足自 备，谁云无分作神仙。 且修真得道，先居蓬莱、方丈、瀛洲，得为散仙，太一元君乃召受图，名题仙籍，以次阶升之跻圣位，上朝玉帝，位号真人。 更须接引后来，溥行开化，至无修证处，乃曰自然。 高真诗云：十月分胎火侯捐，内功时计已三千，更资外行符天道，超脱朝元证上仙。 全真瓦张真人道成之日，作《解佩令词》曰：修行之士，功勤不小，识五行逆顺类倒，妙理玄玄。 玉炉中龙蟠虎踞，金鼎内炼成至宝。 阳神离体，杳杳冥冥，剎那问游遍三岛。 出入纯熟，按捺住，别寻玄妙，合真空，太虚是了。 密语诗五首 嘘呵三尺觅无踪，放去收来疾似风， 十万人中提一二，的将此道付於公。 其二 伸如惊电圆如月，不是男儿莫近前， 证佛成真须用此，这些微妙要师傅。 其三 斩钉截铁剖昏迷，妙用纵横得自师， 适意归来盈袖裹，摩娑恩养作孙儿。 其四 光芒焰焰逼人身，骨悚毛寒作么生， 果是男儿应不怕，一挥当下见真情。 其五 十万人中一二人，一挥要合圣贤心， 赤童显出英灵瑞，枯木开花铁变金。 赞纯阳仙像 至德难名，元功不宰，偈诵何劳称赞。 皇天无私，惟德是辅，圣师因不远焉。 仙姿凤质，命世之真儒，月相虬髯，大唐之宦裔，柢因惊觉黄粮梦，截断输迥生死关，丹成只要度人，位重每来援溺。 下南州则金铅木汞，游汴京则玉液苏迦。 流一振为全真，则亿兆苍生赖其休； 垂三剑为箴规，黝百千弟子蒙其爱。 有时白苹红梦，有时紫府清都，放下般般见太虚，依旧立侍通明殿。 率土想其丰度，寰区昭着灵踪。 郭上鳌久欲归来先生自谓也。 彭道人尚希点化。 即彭冲阳也。 老谬累劫，习气缠绵，有识以来，殊不量力，无所不好，独於仙佛之道，未暇问津。 前辈长沙宦裔岳君素蟾，与吾同好，遂为忘年交。 素知其与彭冲阳、胡古蟾三人法友，同受玉溪先生金丹口诀。 一日因话边扣及，即慨然立谈，平日访友寻师，不惜身命，后遇玉溪老师，吾与子平日无非淡好杂卫，学道自有时节因绿，子既及此，则唯其时矣！ 少俟吉日传授。 遂於甲子辰中，密指数语，谩试为之。 未及一月，丹道即验，所谓金光遍体，琼楼绛阙，龙虎婴姹，须臾恍惚，分明呈现，岳君闻之，因扪泪叹曰：吾闻道以来，身品肉病，不能收足，故於进火工夫，尚未下手。

During the Shaoxing era, in the southern part of Yichun, the household of Prefect Wei of the Wei clan harbored many secrets. One day, an extraordinary person entered directly into his study and called out, "Prefect Wei, come forth for a word." At the time, Wei was napping during the day, and his attendants dared not announce the visitor. The stranger left a *ci* poem on the wall before departing, titled *Sumuzhe*. When Wei awoke and saw it, he deeply regretted the missed encounter and sent men to search, but the visitor could not be found. The poem read:

Within the waters, gold aligns with Ox and Dipper,
Jade locks and golden gates,
Guarded by divine youths of the Dharma.
Red River’s cinnabar terrace—
Dragons and tigers roam,
Myriad forms in solemn array,
Vigorously casting forth the pearl.

Drink from the numinous spring, refine the fire’s timing,
The Great One’s furnace opens,
The elixir ripens, divine radiance pierces through.
Fleeting fame and profit soon fade—
Swiftly begin practice,
Exhaust the "nothing" to attain the "something."
The path to Penglai—
Rely on three thousand deeds fulfilled,
Then stride alone upon the clouds to return.

The *Scripture of the August Void* states: "Those who wish to cultivate the Dao must first establish merit. Thus, the Celestial Emperors of the heavens, the exalted Heavenly Emperors, the Perfected of the heavens, and the Divine Immortals of the heavens all ascend to the sagely and perfected ranks through meritorious deeds. The heavens record merit, and worldly scholars who cultivate the true resolve, once their merit is complete and virtue perfected, shed the mortal to become immortals, transform from immortals to Perfected, and the Perfected attain boundless freedom, merging with spontaneity. When dissolved, they become qi; when at rest, they become human. With spiritual penetrations and self-mastery, they transform without form, soar through the Three Realms, and traverse the hidden and obscure. Cultivators must first cherish essence and treasure qi, anchor the mind and concentrate spirit, establishing the foundation for nurturing the elixir. Then, entering seclusion for three thousand days, the inner work must not be the slightest bit deficient, until the embryo is fully formed, transcending to the primordial origin. Yet external conduct is also essential to accord with the Dao of Heaven. Thus, merit cannot be too abundant, and conduct cannot be too broad. With three thousand merits fulfilled, one becomes an immortal of the Great Veil; with three thousand deeds of conduct fulfilled, one becomes a guest of the Great Veil."

Master Zhongli said: "Merit without conduct is like having no feet; conduct without merit leaves the feet unable to advance. Only with both merit and conduct complete are the feet fully prepared—who then can say one has no share in becoming a divine immortal?"

Moreover, those who cultivate the Dao and attain the Way first dwell in Penglai, Fangzhang, or Yingzhou, becoming unbound immortals. The Primordial Sovereign of the Great One then summons them to receive the chart, their names inscribed in the immortal register, ascending step by step to the sagely ranks, paying court to the Jade Emperor, and receiving the title of Perfected. They must further guide and transform later generations, universally practicing and enlightening, until reaching the state of "no cultivation, no attainment," which is called spontaneity.

A poem by a High Perfected reads:
In the tenth month, the fire’s timing is cast aside,
The inner work’s hours have reached three thousand.
Further relying on external conduct to accord with Heaven’s Dao,
One transcends the primordial origin to verify the Upper Immortal.

When Master Quanzhen Wang and Zhang attained the Dao, they composed the *Ci of Untying the Girdle*, which says:
Cultivators,
Their meritorious efforts are no small matter,
Discerning the reversal and inversion of the five phases,
The wondrous principle is profoundly abstruse.
Within the jade furnace, dragons coil and tigers crouch,
In the golden tripod, the supreme treasure is refined.
The yang spirit departs the body,
Vast and obscure,
In an instant, it roams the three isles.
Once entry and exit are mastered,
Restrain and hold fast,
Seek further mysteries,
Merge with true emptiness—
The Great Void is the culmination.

Five Esoteric Poems:

*Hiss and blow*—three feet, yet no trace,
Release and gather, swift as the wind.
Among a hundred thousand, select one or two,
To entrust this Dao to you.

The second:
Extended like lightning, round as the moon,
Not for men—do not draw near.
To verify Buddhahood or attain Perfection, this is needed,
These subtle wonders require a master.

The third:
Cutting nails and severing iron, cleaving delusion,
The wondrous function, freely applied, comes from the master.
Returning at will, filling the sleeves,
Caress and nurture it as a grandson.

The fourth:
Radiance blazing, pressing upon the body,
Bones tremble, hair stands on end—what to do?
If you are truly a man, you will not fear,
With one stroke, the truth is revealed at once.

The fifth:
Among a hundred thousand, one or two,
With one stroke, it must align with the sages’ minds.
The red youth manifests numinous auspices,
Withered wood blooms, iron turns to gold.

In Praise of the Immortal of Pure Yang:

Supreme virtue defies naming,
Primordial merit does not govern—
What need for gathas or praises?
Heaven is impartial,
Only virtue is aided,
The sagely teacher is never far.

Phoenix-like bearing, a spirit of the age,
A true Confucian of the moon’s visage and dragon beard,
A scion of Tang officials.
Awakened by the Yellow Millet Dream,
He severed the endless cycle of life and death.
Once the elixir was formed, he sought only to deliver others,
His rank exalted, ever aiding the drowning.

In the southern lands, he refined gold lead and wood mercury;
In Bianjing, he savored the jade nectar of Suka.
When he manifested as Quanzhen,
Countless living beings relied on his grace.
Wielding three swords as admonitions,
He nurtured hundreds and thousands of disciples with love.

At times, white duckweed and red reeds;
At times, the Purple Palace and Clear Capital.
Letting go of all, he beheld the Great Void,
Yet still stood in attendance at the Hall of Luminous Understanding.

The realm revered his noble demeanor,
The world witnessed his numinous traces.
Master Guo on the turtle’s back longed to return—
The master spoke of himself thus.
Daoist Peng still awaited enlightenment—
This was Peng Chongyang.

For kalpas, I have been foolish and deluded,
Entangled in habitual tendencies.
Since gaining discernment,
I have never measured my strength,
Indulging in every inclination—
Only the Dao of immortals and Buddhas
Have I not yet inquired into.

My senior, Yue Junsucan of Changsha’s official lineage, shared my passion,
And we became friends despite the difference in age.
I knew he was a dharma companion of Peng Chongyang and Hu Gucan,
All three having received the oral transmission of the Golden Elixir from Master Yuxi.
One day, as we conversed, I broached the subject,
And he spoke with fervor, recounting his lifelong quest for friends and teachers,
Sparing neither body nor life.
Later, he encountered Master Yuxi, who said,
"Our past friendship was but casual discourse and miscellaneous discussions.
The time for learning the Dao has its own season and cause.
Now that you have reached this point, the time is ripe!"
He bade me wait for an auspicious day to transmit the teachings.
Thus, in the *chen* hour of the *jiazi* day,
He secretly imparted a few words,
And I tentatively practiced.
Within a month, the elixir’s efficacy was verified—
The so-called golden radiance suffusing the body,
Jasper towers and crimson palaces,
Dragon and tiger, infant and maiden,
All fleetingly appearing in vision.
When Yue heard of this, he sighed, wiping away tears:
"Since I first heard the Dao,
My body and temperament have been afflicted,
Unable to settle my steps.
Thus, in the work of advancing the fire, I have yet to begin."

The child has long possessed the bone of an immortal—this is no trifling matter. I dare not presume to be your master. Instead, I shall point you to one among them who bears an uncanny resemblance to Master Yuxi. Simply clothe him in robes and cap to capture the likeness of the master, and take him as your teacher. I hereby entrust to you all of the master’s handwritten manuscripts and these ten volumes, with solemn injunctions.

Later, I heard from the modestly learned steward Shu Zongguan: "The master once served in my family. When my father, the Pacification Commissioner, completed his term, we traveled together back to Huai. The master lodged and dined in the kitchen boat, which was tethered to the stern of our vessel with an iron chain. As we neared Zhenzhou, suddenly a great storm arose, and the iron chain snapped. The kitchen boat, with all its people and belongings, was swallowed by the surging waves. Two days later, the master arrived at Yangzi Bridge, clutching a small bundle of clothes. As our boat was being woven together anew, he bid farewell to my father in person and departed. Only then did we realize the master had attained the Dao of entering water without drowning. The Gao family sighed in awe without end."

Since receiving the transmission, fifty-five years have passed, and now I have reached ninety. I have labored to depict the immortal’s likeness at the end of the preface to these ten volumes and have had them engraved to ensure their wide circulation.

On a certain day and month in the fourteenth year of the Zhizheng era, Wang Gui Junzhang of Zhongyang, with incense burning, respectfully inscribed this.
